question: What is the mode of inheritance of Hereditary spherocytosis?
exp: - Hereditary spherocytosis is inherited in an Autosomal dominant pattern. - Results from instability of spectrin & ankyrin which are major skeletal membrane proteins. - Degree of protein deficiency correlates with degree of hemolysis. - Demonstrated by Increase in osmotic fragility after 24hrs incubation of blood at 37oC.

question: The following X-ray findings in skull can be a manifestation of?
exp: - Given X-ray is showing ''Hair on End''' or "Crew Cut appearance - characteristic feature of Thalassemia - It is suggestive of expansion of bone marrow. OTHER CLINICAL FEATURES OF THALASSEMIA: - Hemolytic Facies: Frontal prominence Depressed bridge of nose maxillary prominence - Hepatosplenomegaly (d/t extramedullary hematopoiesis)

question: A 6 years old child belonging to Punjabi family with past history of blood transfusions presented with hemoglobin-3. 5 gm/dL, MCV-30 fL. Peripheral smear findings of microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cell and reduced osmotic fragility. The probable diagnosis of patient:
exp: - Peripheral smear findings of microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cell and reduced osmotic fragility with severe transfusion requiring anemia is suggestive of Beta thalassemia. OTHER OPTIONS: Alpha thalassemia - Doesn't present with severe anemia requiring transfusion Sickle cell anemia - features of sickle cell crisis like hand foot syndrome/ priapism etc are not mentioned in question G6. PD deficiency - No history of oxidative stress is mentioned in the question.

question: Which of the following is not seen on hemoglobin electrophoresis in homozygous sickle cell anemia?
exp: *In homozygous Sickle cell anemia, Hb electrophoresis shows - 80-90% of HbS, rest is HbF and Hb. A2. - However, HbA is absent.

question: Direct Coomb's test is positive in hemolytic anemia due to:
exp: Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria: Caused by the presence of cold-reacting autoantibodies (anti-P Ab) in the blood - Hence, Direct coombs test is positive. Characterized by the sudden presence of hemoglobinuria, typically after exposure to cold temperatures.

question: Best treatment for Sickle cell anemia is?
exp: - Hydroxyurea increases HbF levels - used for treatment of sickle cell anemia. Management of Sickle cell anemia: Avoid infections & prompt correction of any inflammation Pneumococcal & HIB vaccination early in life Acute painful crisis - vigorous hydration & analgesia Bone marrow transplantation, gene therapy Hydroxyurea for patients with severe symptoms

question: A 7-year-old child from West Bengal presented with high grade fever with chills and rigor. Peripheral smear examination revealed Plasmodium vivax. He was given treatment for the same. But he again presented with jaundice, and a repeat peripheral smear showed following. What is your diagnosis?
exp: - Peripheral smear showing 'bite cells' after treatment with anti-malarials - suggests G6. PD deficiency. G6. PD deficiency: X-linked recessive disorder. Most common red cell enzyme deficiency. Hemolysis is seen d/t raised oxidative stress. FEATURES: Pallor, icterus, hemoglobinemia, hemoglobinuria, splenomegaly etc are seen Heinz bodies are seen DRUGS CAUSING OXIDATIVE STRESS IN THESE PATIENTS: Sulfonamides - sulfamethoxazole Anti-malarials - Primaquine, quinine Analgesics - Aspirin, NSAIDS, phenazopyridine (pyridium) Others - Nitrofurantoin, Dapsone, Methylene blue, Rasburicase, Toluidine blue, Nalidixic acid, Furazolidine, quinidine

question: Ba's hydrops fetalis is lethal because:
exp: Hb Ba: Most severe form of Alpha thalassemia As Hb Ba's consists of 4-gamma chains - have very high oxygen affinity Thus, it cannot release oxygen to fetal tissues.
opb: The excess a-globin form insoluble precipitates
opc: Hb Ba's cannot release oxygen to fetal tissues
opd: Microcytic red cells become trapped in the placental

question: A male baby was born in a hospital. After 12 hr of bih, baby was found to be pale. His serum total billirubin level was 20 mg/dl and unconjugated bilirubin was 15 mg/dl, after 36 hr of bih, Hemoglobin was 14 g/dl, and reticulocyte count was high. On peripheral smear, nucleated RBC's and spherocytes are seen. Best possible diagnosis is?
exp: As the neonate has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia along with high reticulocyte count, he seems to be having haemolytic anemia. Spherocytes are seen in Hypehermia Hereditary spherocytosis G6. PD deficiency ABO incompatibility Hereditary spherocytosis is one of the most common reason for Neonatal hyperbilirubinemia along with G6. PD deficiency Diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis is usually based on:- Positive Family history (not mentioned in this case) Splenomegaly (Uncommon in neonates) Spherocytes on Peripheral smear Reticulocytosis Elevated MCHC Increased Osmotic Fragility

question: Most common mutation in hereditary elliptocytosis
exp: - Most common mutation in hereditory elliptocytosis - Spectrin - Inherited as Autosomal Dominant manner - In Spectrin mutations, the most common RBC abnormality is Hereditary Elliptocytosis > spherocytosis.

question: Which of the following condition can result in dactylitis?
exp: - Dactylitis is often first manifestation of pain in infants & young children with sickle cell anemia - Occurs in 50% of children with sickle cell disease by their 2nd year of life - Dactylitis often manifests with symmetric or unilateral swelling of the hands and/or feet.

question: Beta globin missense gene mutation seen in?
exp: - Point mutation (missense) in 6th codon of b-globin gene leading to replacement of glutamic acid by valine residue is seen in sickle cell anemia OTHER OPTIONS: - Common mutations of Beta Thalassemia in India: IVS 1-5 G - C IVS 1-1 G - T Codon 41/42 Codon 819 619 bp deletion - Hb Ba: Most severe form of alpha thalassemia, results from the loss of all four alpha-globin alleles. - HbH: D/t loss of three of four alpha-globin alleles.

question: Which of the following is not associated with a high reticulocyte count?
exp: - High reticulocyte count is seen in: Hemolytic anemias Acute bleeding In response to treatment in nutritional deficiency anemia - Megaloblastic anemia is a nutritional anemia, & it results in low reticulocyte count
opd: Response to treatment in nutrition deficiency anemia
